LGTM, merged after a few fixups.

`AutoCloseable` does not guarantee that it can be closed multiple times -- that's `Closeable`.

Good catch, but this fix doesn't go all the way. Possibilities:

1. The double-close is happening because we allocate two different `AutoCloseable` objects in the try-with-resources block. Inline `writer` into the allocation for `printWriter`, so that there is only one close.

2. If we don't want to use try-with-resources, we should properly handle failures. E.g., make finer-grained `try` blocks and call close in the right `catch` blocks. Or move the `close()` call to a `finally` for a separate `try` after the channel allocation has already succeeded.
Travis failure looks like a network issue on travis or Nexus (it's not able to check artifacts). Triggering a new build.

The problem with the `nvp-test` issue is a little tricky/java-specific, but essentially unrelated. I think your workaround is fine.

```

	at org.apache.beam.sdk.util.SerializableUtils.serializeToByteArray(SerializableUtils.java:53)

	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)

Caused by: java.io.NotSerializableException: org.apache.beam.sdk.options.ValueProviderTest
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject0(ObjectOutputStream.java:1184)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.defaultWriteFields(ObjectOutputStream.java:1548)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeSerialData(ObjectOutputStream.java:1509)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeOrdinaryObject(ObjectOutputStream.java:1432)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject0(ObjectOutputStream.java:1178)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.defaultWriteFields(ObjectOutputStream.java:1548)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeSerialData(ObjectOutputStream.java:1509)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeOrdinaryObject(ObjectOutputStream.java:1432)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject0(ObjectOutputStream.java:1178)
	at java.io.ObjectOutputStream.writeObject(ObjectOutputStream.java:348)
	at org.apache.beam.sdk.util.SerializableUtils.serializeToByteArray(SerializableUtils.java:49)
	... 31 more
```

The key phrase is `Caused by: java.io.NotSerializableException: org.apache.beam.sdk.options.ValueProviderTest`

This is because in Java, anonymous inner classes (your `new SerializableFunction<>(){...}`) automatically include a closure of the things they can reach, including the class they are declared inside of. (`ValueProviderTest`). Since the test class is not itself serializable, the `SerializableFunction` you declared is not serializable.

This rewrite of your test passes:

```java
  private static class NonSerializable {
  }

  private static class NonSerializableProvider implements SerializableFunction<String, NonSerializable> {
    @Override
    public NonSerializable apply(String from) {
      return new NonSerializable();
    }
  }

  @Test
  public void testNestedValueProviderSerialize() throws Exception {
    ValueProvider<String> rvp = StaticValueProvider.of("foo");
    ValueProvider<NonSerializable> nvp = NestedValueProvider.of(
        rvp, new NonSerializableProvider());
    ValueProvider<NonSerializable> nvpCopy = SerializableUtils.ensureSerializable(nvp);
  }
```
Thanks @jkff and @jbonofre for the review and all the comments! I'll make the advised modifications.

It looks like that ended up being a red herring for this test, since all of the translators here aren't using inner classes.  The culprit is 

unable to serialize org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.bigquery.BigQueryIO$BigQueryTableSource@20f12539
        at org.apache.beam.sdk.util.SerializableUtils.serializeToByteArray(SerializableUtils.java:53)

Caused by: java.io.NotSerializableException: org.mockito.internal.creation.DelegatingMethod

... but I'm not seeing how I'm tickling that with my change.

Seems like a useful utility - however, what kind of commands do you envision people will run? Beam gives no guarantees about the runtime environment in which workers execute, so any nontrivial commands, especially those requiring any permissions or credentials, seem out of the question. How do you intend to address this?

I have two use cases where exec could be helpful:
1. trigger update on a data lake, for instance using `distcp`. As `distcp` is part of the Hadoop distribution, it's available on all workers.
2. trigger bootstrapping of some machines. For instance `curl` to interact with Marathon. The only prerequisite is `curl` installed on the workers.

It's two actual use cases that I see, but, obviously, we can imagine other applications.

`distcp` will only be available on workers spawned by Hadoop-based runners, such as Spark, but not on others (e.g. Dataflow or Gearpump). Looks like it can be invoked programmatically from Java in a portable way.

For executing HTTP requests, standard portable Java APIs also seem better than invoking the `curl` command.

In general, it might be OK to write pipelines that are intentionally non-portable between runners, but it seems like something worth discussing on the mailing list first.

Agree, but it's not the same use case. Here, the purpose is to leverage existing commands (like we do with `camel-exec` for instance in the integration space). The purpose is not to have a portable IO, the purpose is to allow DevOps to execute their system commands and scripts (written in `shell`, `perl` or native generally speaking).
The intention is to provide a convenient way to execute such command on processing data directly from a pipeline.
By the way, no problem to discuss this point on the mailing list. As it's an IO, users should "know" why they use the IO depending of their use cases ;)

Okay. Let's discuss on the mailing list the issue of how to deal with transforms that assume that they're running in a particular OS environment, and then resume this review. In particular I'd like to see the following questions addressed:

- How should such transforms be documented? Should they say they're only guaranteed to work in runners X,Y,Z? Should they just say this is best-effort and it is up to the user to ensure that the command makes sense in the environment provided by the runner this user uses, and Beam per se makes no guarantees whatsoever?
- Should runners in general be documenting and providing guarantees on the execution environment?
- Should pipelines be allowed to control the execution environment? (we have `filesToStage`)
- Where should such environment-dependent transforms (like this one) be placed in the Beam source code tree?
- What are the implications of having non-portable transforms like this at all? E.g., obviously, anything that uses this transform also becomes non-portable.

Assuming these issues are resolved, I'm wondering if a transform is needed at all. It seems like all the nontrivial code is in ExecFn.processElement() - would it be sufficient to provide a single static function "String executeCommand(String command, String workingDirectory, long timeout)" and let the user wrap it into DoFn's whichever way makes most sense in their pipeline?
LGTM if this compiles. And/or wait for Jenkins.

@kennknowles says he'd like to pass the review to @tgroh (with some followup offline comments), so
R: @tgroh
Merging this now, but for future reference version pinning should probably be its own commit (and PR).
I'm OK with moving on with this since PRs to clean it up are already in place.

Consistency is good, but the direct runner's design is better. The symmetry already exists and lies between construction and `finishBundle()`. Why do you need to wait to start the bundle, given that the bundle's arrival is what caused the evaluator to exist?

Patterns of `start()` and `finish()` are nicely expressed as an object representing the start-to-finish lifecycle, a la `Closeable` or Python's context managers whenever possible. It is much less error prone, hence its popularization. Even without language support, it is pretty easy to use a similar discipline.

My motivating example was code related to Splittable DoFn that looks like this:
```
evaluator = ParDoEvaluator.create(processFn)
...wire up processFn with evaluator...
processFn.setup()
return evaluator;
```
and this was failing cause `ParDoEvaluator.create()` called `processFn.startBundle()` and that expects `setup()` to already be called.

I can just call `setup()` earlier, but it logically makes more sense to call `setup()` on a fully prepared `processFn`.

I like the start-to-finish lifecycle pattern, but it doesn't play well with cyclic dependencies like this, where you need to wire some objects together and only then kick off the processing.

@tgroh WDYT?

Thanks. In addition to the code comments, here's a comment on the test failures:

https://api.travis-ci.org/jobs/179871973/log.txt?deansi=true and https://api.travis-ci.org/jobs/179871974/log.txt?deansi=true have similar failures:

```

	at org.eclipse.paho.client.mqttv3.persist.MqttDefaultFilePersistence.restoreBackups(MqttDefaultFilePersistence.java:273)
	at org.eclipse.paho.client.mqttv3.persist.MqttDefaultFilePersistence.open(MqttDefaultFilePersistence.java:120)

	at org.apache.beam.sdk.io.mqtt.MqttIO$ConnectionConfiguration.getClient(MqttIO.java:149)
	at org.apache.beam.sdk.io.mqtt.MqttIO$ConnectionConfiguration.access$300(MqttIO.java:128)
	at org.apache.beam.sdk.io.mqtt.MqttIO$Write$WriteFn.createMqttClient(MqttIO.java:584)
```

According to https://github.com/andypiper/paho-mqtt/blob/master/org.eclipse.paho.client.mqttv3/src/main/java/org/eclipse/paho/client/mqttv3/persist/MqttDefaultFilePersistence.java (that code unfortunately doesn't include any information in the exceptions it throws), this means there are no files under the persistence directory. Why could this be? This needs to be investigated and fixed before merging, since otherwise other people are going to keep hitting the same error in their Travis runs of unrelated PRs.
